On Wed, Jan 4, 2012 at 5:51 AM, Jan Algermissen
<jan.algermissen@...> wrote:

> I do not refer to generic forms. A form is any syntactical construct that instructs
> the user agent what data to include in the submission (including fixed (aka
> 'hidden')) values. My forms would simply be an inherent part of the specific
> media type(s) I define.

What makes the "form" stand out from any other part of the data, and
why should it stand out from any part of the data. The client will
need to "know" how to build the "form" for the payload anyway, and it
can source that data from any part of the original payload as required
by the specifics of the call, whether that source data is from a
"form" or simply part of the data.

Why does the "form" part stand out at all?

Regards,

Will Hartung
(willh@...)
